title: 103_s1049
content: The "Lechuguilla Cave Protection Act of 1993" aims to protect significant cave resources in Carlsbad Caverns National Park and adjacent public lands from adverse effects of mineral exploration and development. The Act defines terms like "cave protection area" and "Secretary" and emphasizes the importance of retaining these areas in public ownership. The "Lechuguilla Cave Protection Act of 1993" withdraws approximately 6,280 acres of public lands within the cave protection area from all forms of appropriation or disposal under public land laws. The lands are described in a map filed with the House of Representatives and the Committee on Energy. The "Lechuguilla Cave Protection Act of 1993" withdraws public lands from appropriation under public land laws. The Secretary manages the withdrawn lands through the Bureau of Land Management in accordance with relevant laws. Copies of the map and legal description are available for public inspection. SEC. 5. MANAGEMENT OF EXISTING LEASES. The Secretary is prohibited from allowing new drilling on valid mineral or geothermal leases within certain lands to protect cave resources. The suspension of activities on these leases will remain until a decision is made on the drilling proposal or for 12 months after the enactment of the Act. During the specified period, the Secretary will negotiate with lease holders to terminate or restrict activities on public lands to protect cave resources. The value of unrecoverable oil and gas resources will be considered in these agreements. During the specified period, the Secretary will negotiate with lease holders to terminate or restrict activities on public lands to protect cave resources. If no agreement is reached, the Secretary will take appropriate steps to protect Lechuguilla Cave and other significant cave resources in Carlsbad Caverns National Park. This may include acquiring the lands covered by the lease. The Secretary will seek cooperation from the State of New Mexico and other landowners in the cave protection area to implement restrictions for the protection of Lechuguilla Cave and other resources in Carlsbad Caverns National Park. SEC. 6. ADDITIONAL PROTECTION AND RELATION TO OTHER LAWS. The Secretary shall take additional steps to protect Lechuguilla Cave and other significant cave resources in Carlsbad Caverns National Park, including limiting access and prohibiting removal of resources, if deemed necessary based on scientific analysis. If existing laws are insufficient, the Secretary may take further actions to protect the cave. The Secretary may inform relevant committees if additional authority is needed to protect Lechuguilla Cave or other significant cave resources in Carlsbad Caverns National Park. This Act does not affect the ability to seek compensation under existing laws, such as the Tucker Act.
